"Cinema has a particularly
powerful relationship to memory.

2265.92.text:
There's nothing that
does memory like cinema."

2267.71.text: And I very much agree with that.

2270.14.text:
And cinema -- so for me, is part
of this constructing process.

2274.71.text: But you're absolutely spot on in

2276.57.text:
that this isn't necessarily
a reflection of reality.

2279.58.text:
Oh, I'm sorry -- not necessarily
an accurate depiction

2284.07.text:
But for me, the fancy
is the interesting part.

2286.35.text:
I mean, the ways in which we
construct the '60's tell us

2289.34.text:
so much about how we now
respond to the '60's.

2292.18.text:
How we now [inaudible] the '60's
and how the '60's been produced

2294.59.text:
and reproduced and reproduced
and reproduced since then.

2297.34.text:
And so, I mean we are interested
in what we can corroborate.

2300.10.text:
We are interested in what
this tells us about the '60's

2302.81.text:
and what actually happened,
but we're also interested

2306.07.text:
in this notion of construction,
this notion of fantasy,

2308.43.text:
this notion of the '60's as kind
of a mythical period as a period

2312.84.text:
that happened, but
has since had kind

2315.45.text:
of particular myths
built around it.

2317.71.text:
And so, yes you're right to flag
that up and thank you for that.

2322.39.text:
But it's something that we
are interested in certainly.

>> [Inaudible] as someone
